Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Amy Jordan of University of Washington to conduct a research project, entitled "Identifying starch residues on pots from early Colonial plantation sites in the Banda Islands, Maluku Province, Indonesia" during the summer of 2012 at University of New South Wales in Syndey, Australia. The host scientist is Judith Field.

The Intellectual Merit of the research includes using an underutilized research technique on artifacts from a little-studied area and time period. The Banda Islands were the location of early experiments in colonialism by European powers and research into various aspects of European occupation can provide information for cross cultural studies of the different responses to colonialism. A starch grain analysis of food residue on ceramic sherds from colonial plantations in the Banda Islands gives direct evidence of dietary choices in this time period, a period of intense social change. This evidence is then used in conjunction with historical records to determine if ethnic background may have influenced food choice during the colonial period. Using this underutilized analytical technique to investigate colonial era archaeological remains will add to the growing body of Neolithic and pre-colonial archaeology conducted in the Banda Islands.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Australia: Starch Grain Analysis of Potsherds at Colonial Plantation Sites in the Banda Islands, Maluku Province, Indonesia

 

Pottery fragments excavated from colonial period plantations in the Banda Islands, Maluku Province, Indonesia were analyzed for the remains of starches. The Banda Islands were the location of early experiments in colonialism and the establishment of cash-crop plantations by European powers; research into various aspects of European occupation can provide information for cross cultural studies of the different responses to colonialism. The starch grains yield information on the changes in diet before and after colonization of the islands by the Dutch. The starch grain analysis is used in conjunction with historical records to determine what social and environmental factors may have influenced food choice during the colonial period.

For this project, 108 potsherds from three colonial period plantation sites were selected to undergo starch grain analysis. Sherds were subject to starch grain analysis following protocols established by Judith Field (Senior Research Fellow, University of New South Wales), the sponsor for this project. Both imported porcelain/ tradeware and locally produced earthenware sherds were selected for analysis, assuming that these items were associated with different levels of status in the plantation society. Sherds were submerged in a sonicated bath to remove the adhering residue. This residue was then subjected to a heavy liquid density separation to remove the starch grains. The residue was mounted on microscope slides and examined under a polarized light microscope.

Of the 108 samples, only 20% (N=22) yielded any starch residue. Porcelain/ tradeware yielded slightly higher rates of residue with 5 of the 16 sherds, or 31%, yielding residue. Only 18%, or 17 of 92, of the earthenware sherds yielded starch residue. Few of the starch grains have been definitively identified at this time. However, some conclusions can be drawn.

Historic records indicate that rice was the preferred starch after the Dutch conquest. I expected to find copious amounts of rice starch on both porcelain/ tradeware, which was assumed to be used by the elites, and the lower quality earthenware, which was assumed to be used by the workers and slaves on the plantations. The assumption of a rice-based diet based on historic records proved to be unsupported by the archaeological evidence. Of the 22 sherds with starch residue, only three yielded rice grains and two of these yielded both rice and non-rice starch grains. The lack of rice grains found on the sherds indicates there was a lack of rice at the plantations, despite historical records claiming workers were being provided rice rations.  However, rice was found on at least one earthenware sherd indicating that the assumed lower status ceramics were also being used for either rice storage or serving. As the vast majority of starch that was found was not rice, this supports the continuation of pre-colonial trade routes or the existence of extra-governmental trade. The predominance of non-rice starch grains indicates that the inhabitants of the plantations were not receiving or not accepting the rations in favor of alternative starches, probably sago or possibly sweet potato based on large grain sizes.

The tantalizing results thus far do suggest a creolization, or cultural mixing, of foodways with the presence of both higher status rice and lower status non-rice grains on the assumed higher status porcelain sherds at the plantation.
